ygData.subject: Re: [neat] Re: Introduction---recurrency question
ygData.msgSnippet: ... Well, NEAT doesn t address this specifically but I m not sure what you re saying here.  It s certainly handled by NEAT as well as anything else

> > I am moving towards something much more complex.  I would like to
> > try and implement NEAT+Hawkins(On Intelligence) ideas on how the
> > brain works.  This requires more complex structures that allow, for
> > instance, for recurrent connections back to *input* nodes.
> 
> Yes, outputs are inputs.  It's all a big loop.  But it's more than
> just that...  When the 'expected' input (which is an output of an
> 'expectation' circuit) doesn't match the input, you get one result. 
> When it does, you get another.  But that kind of thing is VERY
> different than NEAT.
> 

Well, NEAT doesn't address this specifically but I'm not sure what you're
saying here.  It's certainly "handled" by NEAT as well as anything else
(seemingly better in some cases).

> 
> > there is also a strong temporal aspect to this according to
> > hawkins.  incorporating both the feedback and temporal aspects into
> > a net raises the level of complexity quite a bit.  Hawkins team has
> > implemented a fixed structure hierarchy that is not really a NN.  It
> > uses bayesian probabilities throughout the feedback mechanism.
> > Their early tests show some real promise in invariant visual
> > recognition...but I feel their structure is too constrained and
> > would like to see if NEAT can be applied with his concepts
> > incorporated.  It may not work or may be too complex...I dunno...
> 
> I don't think NEAT is what you want.  I think you want a dynamic
> network that grows during the life of the organism.  Which means you
> need a set of rules governing that growth.  Evolution might best be
> applied to those rules, rather than to the structure itself.
> 

I disagree.  I think this is exactly the sort of thing NEAT would excel at. 
Any time you have recurrency, there are "temporal aspects" but it's just a
higher order of topology.  In fact, NEAT is evolving rules for building
structure, just not at the same level you're suggesting here (a la cellular
automata).  Growth over the life of the organism is interesting and something
I'm not experienced with.  When our brains "grow" is that out of necessity or
opportunity?

As for Bayesian networks, I believe it's just another spin on the same
problem.  Someone correct me if I'm wrong, but I believe anything that can be
done by a bayesian network can in theory be done with a NN.

Regards,

jeff
